Application Performance Monitoring (APM).description: Provides core distributed tracing for Java applications by automatically instrumenting popular frameworks and libraries. Captures performance metrics and traces requests across microservices to identify bottlenecks and latency issues.

This file defines the `Taintable` interface, which is used to mark objects originating from untrusted sources, typically for Interactive Application Security Testing (IAST). It includes methods to associate a source with the object and a utility for debugging tainted instances.

This file defines the `PropagationModule` interface, which is the main API for managing and propagating tainted values within Datadog's IAST (Interactive Application Security Testing) module. It provides methods to mark objects and strings as tainted, based on various criteria and ranges.

Defines an interface for modules to hook into and observe various encoding, decoding, and data conversion operations (like URL encoding/decoding, Base64, and string-byte conversions) for IAST purposes.

This interface defines methods for modules to intercept and analyze common string manipulation operations, such as concatenation, formatting, and case changes. It serves as a hook for IAST (Interactive Application Security Testing) to track the origin and flow of string data.
This class provides a helper method to apply security marks to objects. It uses the IAST propagation module to mark objects as tainted, aiding in security control mechanisms.

Provides utility methods for Datadog's IAST (Interactive Application Security Testing) to propagate taint information across various application operations, such as URI creation and string manipulations. It serves as an internal bridge to delegate these events to specific IAST propagation modules for taint tracking.
This file defines a Spring Security filter that extracts a JWT token from the 'Authorization' header and sets it as the authentication in the SecurityContextHolder for subsequent processing.
This file implements a Spring Security AuthenticationProvider responsible for validating JSON Web Tokens (JWTs) and authenticating users based on the claims within the token.

This file defines a custom Spring Security `Authentication` implementation for JWT-based authentication. It stores the JWT, its parsed payload, and associated user details to represent an authenticated user.

This file configures Spring Security for a resource server to protect endpoints using JWTs, including setting up a JWT decoder, token validators (timestamp, issuer, audience), and defining access rules based on scopes and authorities.

This directory contains Groovy-based unit and integration tests for the internal API's Interactive Application Security Testing (IAST) security control features. It ensures the correct functionality and behavior of security control mechanisms within the `dd-trace-java` internal API.

Provides helper methods for instrumenting Java process execution, including command redaction, span completion hooks, and RASP checks for command and shell injection, designed for bootstrap classloader injection.
This is a marker interface used to identify advice implementations that utilize `@CallSite` annotations for RASP (Runtime Application Self-Protection) related call sites.

This class implements Datadog's Application Security (AppSec) event tracker, responsible for recording user authentication activities, user tracking, and custom security events. It manages user ID anonymization, integrates with the WAF for metrics, and can initiate blocking actions.
Defines the CallbackProvider interface, which allows producers to retrieve specific callbacks based on an event type, and includes a no-op implementation.

This file defines an interface for committing a blocking response, typically used in security features to prevent further request processing. It includes methods to handle different blocking scenarios and ensures the associated trace segment is marked as blocked.
This file defines the `RequestContext` interface, which serves as a context object carrying request-specific data that travels with a request and is presented to instrumentation gateway subscribers.
This file defines and enumerates all known event types (e.g., request started, response ended, database query) that the DataDog Java tracer's instrumentation gateway can handle and react to.

This interface defines methods for accessing and modifying span-related information, including trace and span IDs, tags, and request blocking actions. It provides a gateway for interacting with span data within the tracing system.

This file defines a central gateway for registering and retrieving callbacks associated with various application events, primarily for security instrumentation (AppSec and IAST). It ensures safe execution of these callbacks by wrapping them to handle exceptions.

Provides factory methods for creating and managing stored request body objects (byte-based or character-based) for processing by security features (AppSec) within the Datadog tracer. It facilitates the capture and delivery of request body data, often interacting with a callback mechanism for body processing events.

This class incrementally stores and manages character-based HTTP body data, allowing for appending various character data types. It notifies a gateway about body read events and can trigger blocking actions if size limits are reached or security policies are violated.
Manages the incremental storage and decoding of byte streams into character sequences, handling different charsets and providing mechanisms to append byte data chunks.

This file defines a static API (`EventTrackerV2`) for tracking user login events (success/failure) and custom events within the AppSec module. It acts as a facade, delegating event tracking to an underlying `EventTrackerService` implementation.
This file defines the `EventTrackerService` interface, which provides an API for tracking user login success and failure events, as well as custom application security events.
Defines a custom runtime exception, `BlockingException`, used within the Datadog Application Security (AppSec) API to signify that a request has been blocked.

This file defines the public API for the AppSec subsystem's request blocking functionality, allowing applications to initiate and commit blocking responses for users or requests. It provides methods to block users based on specific criteria and to commit HTTP blocking responses.

This file defines the `BlockingService` interface for application security (AppSec), providing methods to determine if a user should be blocked and to commit blocking responses. It also includes a no-operation (NOOP) implementation for cases where blocking is not active.

This Spring Boot controller demonstrates and tests the Datadog AI Guard API by defining various endpoints that trigger AI Guard evaluations, and it also provides a mock implementation for AI Guard's evaluation REST API for smoke testing purposes.

This file defines configuration property names and their default values for Datadog's AI Guard feature within the `dd-trace-java` project. It includes settings for enabling AI Guard, its endpoint, timeouts, and content size limits.

This file provides a no-operation (noop) implementation of the AI Guard Evaluator, which always allows requests and indicates that AI Guard is not enabled. It serves as a placeholder when AI Guard functionality is intentionally disabled.

This file defines a simple `Token` class that encapsulates a Spring Security `Jwt` object and its associated `GrantedAuthority` collection, likely used for handling authenticated user tokens and their permissions.

This directory is intended to house Groovy-based test files for the internal Application Security (AppSec) API components of the Datadog Java tracer. Its purpose is to validate the functionality and integration of these security-related internal APIs.

This file defines an abstract class, HttpClientPayload, which encapsulates HTTP client request or response data, including request ID, headers, content type, and body. It serves as a base for handling payload information within Datadog's application security tracing.

This file defines the `HttpClientRequest` class, which represents an HTTP client request within the Datadog application security tracing API. It encapsulates request details such as the URL, HTTP method, and headers for security analysis.
Represents an HTTP client response within the Datadog application security context. It encapsulates the response's status code and headers, linked to a specific request ID.

This class defines an immutable object to represent a media type (MIME type), parsing content type strings into their component parts (type, subtype, charset) and providing utility methods for common checks like `isJson`.
This file defines the `EventType` class, a generic type used to uniquely identify various events within the system by associating a name and an ID.
Defines the `Subscription` interface, which represents a handle to an event subscription allowing it to be cancelled. It also includes a no-operation implementation for convenience.

This file defines the `SubscriptionService` interface, which provides an API for consumers to register callbacks for various event types. It also includes a no-op implementation for scenarios where no active subscription service is available.
This enum defines distinct slots for various components (e.g., AppSec, CI_VISIBILITY, IAST) within a request context, allowing different features to store and retrieve their specific data.

This file defines the `Flow` interface, which encapsulates the result of an event and an associated action, including specific types for blocking requests with HTTP status codes and headers. It is used by the API gateway to decide how to proceed after processing an event, particularly for security-related blocking.
Defines an interface, `StoredBodySupplier`, that acts as a supplier for a `CharSequence` representing a stored HTTP body. This allows for deferred or repeated access to HTTP body content.

This file defines the `IastDetectionMode` enum, which specifies different operational modes for IAST (Interactive Application Security Testing). It provides abstract methods for configuring IAST parameters like request limits, sampling, and deduplication based on the selected mode.

This file provides an instrumentation bridge for Datadog's IAST (Interactive Application Security Testing) modules, acting as a central registry to register and access various security analysis modules.

This file defines a comprehensive enumeration of security vulnerability types as byte constants for use within Datadog's IAST (Interactive Application Security Testing) API. It includes utility methods for converting these types to string representations and for grouping related vulnerabilities.

This file provides utility methods for checking various conditions related to the enablement and configuration of IAST (Interactive Application Security Testing) features, such as Java version compatibility and IAST detection modes.

This file defines a utility class that provides bit masks (flags) for various types of security vulnerabilities within the IAST system. It allows representing and combining different vulnerability types efficiently using bitwise operations.

This file defines the `IastModule` interface, a core component for Datadog's Interactive Application Security Testing (IAST) functionality. It provides common logging utilities and an `@OptOut` annotation to exclude types from IAST analysis.

This file defines the `SecurityControl` class, a data structure used to represent and store information about a specific security control, including its type, target method details, and associated parameters to be marked.

This class parses a string-based configuration of security controls, converting it into a structured map of `SecurityControl` objects for internal use. It extracts details such as control type, vulnerability marks, target class, method, and parameters from a delimited input string.
This file defines an enumeration, `SecurityControlType`, specifying different categories of security controls within the Datadog IAST API, such as input validators and sanitizers.
This file defines the `SourceMapper` interface, which provides a mechanism to map a class name and a line number to its corresponding source file path and line number.
This file defines a data structure for representing an HTTP cookie, including its various attributes, and provides a builder pattern for its convenient construction.

This file defines constant string names for configuration options related to IAST (Interactive Application Security Testing) features within the Datadog Java tracer, such as enabling IAST, configuring vulnerability detection, and setting performance limits.
Defines constant string names for configuration options related to Datadog Application Security (AppSec) and API Security features.
This file defines constants for configuration keys related to Cloud Workload Security (CWS) within the Datadog Java tracer API. It provides keys for enabling CWS and configuring TLS refresh settings.
Defines the possible content types (e.g., HTML, JSON, or auto-detected) for responses generated when an application security block is triggered.
This class defines the details for an application security blocking action, including the HTTP status code, content type, and any additional headers to be sent in the blocking response.

This file defines the `UserService` interface within the Datadog Application Security API, providing a contract for tracking user-related events with associated metadata. It includes a no-operation (NO_OP) implementation for convenience.
This file defines the public API for the Datadog Application Security (AppSec) user service, allowing developers to set user IDs and associated metadata for monitoring purposes.

This utility extracts and categorizes sensitive data paths (redaction rules) from AWS SDK 'service-2.json' definition files. It identifies sensitive fields within request, response, and error payloads based on their 'sensitive' property.

This directory contains Groovy-based test code for the internal API components of Datadog's Java tracer. Specifically, these tests validate functionalities related to Interactive Application Security Testing (IAST) concerning the handling and detection of sensitive secrets.

This file defines an interface for an IAST (Interactive Application Security Testing) module responsible for detecting and reporting hardcoded secrets in application code. It specifies a method for notifying when a hardcoded secret is found, including its value, location, and class context.

This file defines a collection of regular expressions and associated metadata for identifying various types of hardcoded secrets, such as API keys and access tokens, across different platforms and services. It serves as a central registry for secret detection patterns within the Datadog tracing library's IAST module.

This file defines a standalone sampler for Application Security Monitoring (ASM) that ensures at least one APM trace per minute is sampled, even without ASM events, to maintain service 'liveness' for billing and catalog purposes.

This file defines a periodic action specifically designed for collecting IAST (Interactive Application Security Testing) metrics within the Datadog telemetry system. It ensures that the correct IAST metric collector is used for periodic metric submission.
This file defines a periodic action responsible for collecting Web Application Firewall (WAF) related metrics for telemetry purposes, specifically by returning a WafMetricCollector.

This directory contains Groovy-based unit or integration tests for the telemetry components of the Interactive Application Security Testing (IAST) internal API within the Datadog Java Tracer. Its role is to validate the proper functioning and reporting of IAST-related metrics and data.
Defines an enumeration for different verbosity levels (OFF, MANDATORY, INFORMATION, DEBUG) and provides methods to check if a specific verbosity level is enabled.

Defines an enumeration of IAST (Interactive Application Security Testing) metrics, specifying their names, scope, commonality, verbosity levels, and associated tags for telemetry and tracing within the Datadog ecosystem.

This class provides a mechanism to collect and manage IAST (Interactive Application Security Testing) metrics, supporting both global and request-scoped aggregation. It accumulates metric counts and facilitates their draining for reporting purposes.

This Java enum defines different types of WAF (Web Application Firewall) truncation reasons, such as strings being too long or objects being too deep. Each truncation type is associated with a unique integer value.

Defines an enumeration of security rule types, such as LFI, SQL Injection, and SSRF, along with their associated types and variants for telemetry reporting. This categorizes various security vulnerabilities or detections.

This file defines a singleton class responsible for collecting and managing various metrics related to the Web Application Firewall (WAF), Runtime Application Self-Protection (RASP), and AI Guard features. It tracks events such as WAF requests, rule evaluations, errors, and input truncations, preparing them for telemetry reporting.

This file defines the `@Sink` annotation, used to mark methods or types as sinks for specific vulnerability types in Datadog's IAST (Interactive Application Security Testing). It associates a byte value representing the vulnerability type with the annotated element.
Defines an IAST module interface for detecting and handling header injection vulnerabilities. It specifies a callback method to be invoked when a header is processed.

Defines an interface for a module that tracks and handles reflection-related operations, such as class, method, or field name usage, for security analysis against reflection injection vulnerabilities.

This interface defines a module for tracking and handling HTTP response headers and cookies within the IAST (Interactive Application Security Testing) framework. It specifies methods to be called when a response header or cookie is set, acting as a sink for security analysis.

This file defines an interface for an IAST (Interactive Application Security Testing) module specifically designed to detect or report LDAP Injection vulnerabilities. It provides a hook for monitoring directory context search operations, which are potential sinks for such vulnerabilities.

This file defines the interface for an IAST (Interactive Application Security Testing) module responsible for detecting Server-Side Request Forgery (SSRF) vulnerabilities. It specifies a method to be called when a URL connection is made, enabling security analysis at that point.
Defines an interface for an IAST (Interactive Application Security Testing) module responsible for detecting insecure authentication protocols, typically at the end of an HTTP request.

This file defines the `ApplicationModule` interface for Datadog IAST, specifying methods to monitor application-level security-sensitive operations such as handling real paths and checking session tracking modes.

This file defines an interface for an IAST module responsible for detecting and reporting instances of weak randomness usage within an application. It provides a callback method to be invoked when a weak random number generator is identified.

This interface defines the contract for an IAST (Interactive Application Security Testing) module responsible for detecting or monitoring unvalidated redirect vulnerabilities. It specifies methods to be called when redirect operations or relevant header settings occur.

This file defines an IAST module interface specifically designed to detect or monitor email injection vulnerabilities. It provides a hook, `onSendEmail`, for security analysis when an application dispatches an email.
This interface defines the contract for an IAST module responsible for detecting SQL injection vulnerabilities. It specifies methods to be called when JDBC queries are executed.
Defines an IAST module interface for detecting and handling stacktrace leaks, providing a callback method to report such incidents with relevant contextual information.

This file defines an interface for modules within the IAST framework that are responsible for detecting security vulnerabilities associated with HTTP cookies. It provides a method to check if a given cookie is vulnerable.

This file defines an interface for IAST modules that perform actions or checks at the end of an HTTP request. It includes helper methods to identify HTML responses and ignorable HTTP status codes for security analysis.
This file defines the `InsecureCookieModule` interface within Datadog's IAST API, serving as a marker or handler for identifying insecure HTTP cookies as a security 'sink'.

This file defines the interface for an IAST (Interactive Application Security Testing) module designed to detect XPath Injection vulnerabilities. It specifies a method to be called when an XPath expression is encountered, serving as a sink for this type of vulnerability.

Defines an interface for an IAST (Interactive Application Security Testing) module dedicated to detecting or monitoring untrusted deserialization vulnerabilities. It provides a method to hook into the deserialization process of an object.

This file defines an internal API interface for the Datadog IAST (Instrumentation-based Application Security Testing) module. It specifies methods to be called when Java applications execute external commands, enabling the detection of command injection vulnerabilities.

This file defines the `XContentTypeModule` interface, an IAST module designed to detect or handle security vulnerabilities related to the X-Content-Type-Options HTTP header at the end of a request, and it is opt-out by default.

This file defines an internal API interface for an IAST (Interactive Application Security Testing) module. Its purpose is to provide a hook for monitoring and reporting the use of cipher algorithms, particularly to identify weak ciphers within an application.

This file defines the `TrustBoundaryViolationModule` interface, part of Datadog's IAST API. It specifies a method for identifying or reporting trust boundary violations that occur when processing session values.

This file defines the `NoHttpOnlyCookieModule` interface, an IAST module used to detect HTTP cookies that are missing the `HttpOnly` security flag. It extends `HttpCookieModule` and is marked for opt-out behavior.

This file defines the `XssModule` interface, part of the IAST API, for reporting Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) vulnerabilities. It includes various `onXss` methods to capture different types of XSS occurrences with details about the tainted data.

This file defines an interface for an IAST (Interactive Application Security Testing) module dedicated to detecting path traversal vulnerabilities. It specifies methods to be called when various forms of path manipulation that could lead to path traversal are observed.

This file defines an internal API interface for an IAST module that detects and reports the use of hashing algorithms. It serves as a sink for identifying potential security vulnerabilities related to weak hashing.

This file defines a marker interface for an IAST (Interactive Application Security Testing) module that detects the absence of the HSTS (HTTP Strict Transport Security) header at the end of an HTTP request. It signifies a security misconfiguration sink within the Datadog tracing library.
This file defines an internal API interface for Datadog's Java IAST module, specifically representing a 'sink' for detecting 'No SameSite Cookie' vulnerabilities, which can be optionally disabled.

CI Test & Pipeline Visibility.description: Offers insights into CI/CD pipeline performance by tracking test executions, identifying flaky tests, and providing visibility into build and test durations. Helps optimize testing suites and improve developer productivity.

files.description: This directory is intended to contain Groovy source files for smoke tests specifically targeting Ratpack version 1.5. These tests are part of the `dd-smoke-tests` suite within the Datadog Java tracer repository, verifying integration and functionality with this particular framework version.

This directory is designated to contain Groovy-based smoke tests for the command-line interface (CLI) component of the `dd-trace-java` project. It functions as a package for critical, high-level verification tests that ensure core CLI functionalities are working as expected.
This file contains a functional test for a custom Gradle plugin, verifying that it can be applied to a project and execute a 'hello' task which prints a specific message.

This file defines a JUnit 4 test class (`TestSucceedC`) that performs basic addition assertions and is used in smoke tests to verify successful test execution, potentially in conjunction with class ordering.

This is a JUnit 4 test class used in smoke tests to demonstrate successful test execution. It also exemplifies the use of `@OrderWith(Alphanumeric.class)` for controlling the execution order of test methods within the class.

This JUnit 4 test class, part of the `dd-trace-java` smoke tests, demonstrates and verifies alphanumeric test method ordering. It contains simple assertions designed to succeed, focusing on the ordering mechanism.
This file contains a JUnit 5 test case for Datadog's smoke tests, specifically verifying a basic successful operation using a Calculator utility.
This is a JUnit test class designed for smoke testing within the Datadog trace Java project, verifying basic functionality and including a test intended for skipping with ITR.

This JUnit test file contains two passing tests designed to verify successful test execution within a smoke test suite, specifically for an older Gradle environment. It serves as a basic verification that the test infrastructure is functional.
This JUnit test file is designed to intentionally fail, serving as a smoke test case to verify how the tracing system handles failing tests, specifically in a legacy instrumentation context.
This file contains JUnit 5 smoke tests designed to always succeed, verifying basic functionality and potentially demonstrating test skipping features.

This JUnit test case, part of the dd-smoke-tests suite, defines a simple test that always passes. It likely serves to verify basic test execution even when other configurations, possibly corrupted or new instrumentation, are present in the testing environment.
This is a basic JUnit test case within a multi-module smoke test suite, designed to simply pass and verify fundamental test execution within a new instrumentation setup.
This JUnit test file, `TestSucceed.java`, serves as a basic smoke test to confirm successful test execution within a multi-module legacy instrumentation environment.

This file contains JUnit tests designed to always succeed, verifying basic calculator operations. It serves as a smoke test within the `dd-trace-java` project, including a test intended for Intelligent Test Runner (ITR) skipping.
This file defines a JUnit 4 smoke test class `TestSucceedA`. It contains a simple test method to verify a basic arithmetic operation.
A simple JUnit 4 test class with a single passing test, likely used as part of a smoke test suite to verify basic functionality or test runner behavior.
This file is a JUnit 4 test class, part of Datadog's smoke tests, designed to demonstrate a simple successful test case for a Calculator's add method.
This is a JUnit 4 smoke test class containing two successful tests, demonstrating alphanumeric test method ordering within a Maven test suite.

This file defines a JUnit 4 test class, `TestSucceedC`, which contains basic passing tests and is part of a smoke test suite designed to verify successful Maven execution and JUnit 4 test class ordering.
This file defines JUnit tests for basic arithmetic operations within the Datadog Java tracer's smoke test suite. It ensures that the tests succeed as part of a Maven Surefire execution.

This JUnit test file is intentionally designed to fail. It likely serves as a smoke test to verify how the system handles failed or flaky test executions, especially in scenarios involving Maven test retries.

This Java file contains JUnit test cases (TestSucceed) for a Calculator class, specifically asserting addition and subtraction operations. It is part of a smoke test suite, likely for testing Datadog's tracing capabilities in a Maven environment with JaCoCo.

This JUnit test class (`TestSucceed.java`) contains basic assertion tests for a `Calculator` class, designed to verify core functionality within a Maven smoke test suite. It includes tests for addition and subtraction, both expected to pass.
This JUnit test file contains a simple test that asserts `2 + 2 = 4`, likely used as part of a smoke test suite to confirm basic test execution in a Maven project.
This Java class provides basic arithmetic operations (addition and subtraction). It likely serves as a simple utility or example class within the `dd-trace-java` smoke tests.
This file contains JUnit tests specifically designed to fail, likely for demonstrating or testing error handling and test replay mechanisms in a Maven project.

This file contains JUnit tests intentionally designed to fail, serving as a component of smoke tests for Datadog's Java tracer to verify the handling and reporting of failed tests by its test management system.
This is a JUnit test class that performs a basic arithmetic assertion, expected to succeed. It likely serves as a smoke test or to verify test management integration within a Maven build.
This file contains Cucumber step definitions for testing a simple calculator application, along with an embedded calculator implementation used in the tests.

This file is a Cucumber test runner for smoke tests, configured to execute the 'basic_arithmetic.feature' using the 'datadog.smoke.calculator' glue. It serves as an integration test to verify a successful Maven build that includes Cucumber tests.

This directory is intended to hold test resources for Datadog smoke tests, specifically those executed within a Maven project utilizing Cucumber. It likely provides configuration or data necessary for a test scenario designed to verify successful Maven run outcomes. The path indicates its role within a `test_successful_maven_run_with_cucumber` test case.

This JUnit test verifies that a system property named "my-custom-property" is correctly set to "provided-via-command-line" during its execution. It likely serves as a smoke test for Maven builds to ensure system properties are properly passed into the test environment.
This OSGi Bundle Activator manages the lifecycle of a `MessageClient` for an OSGi smoke test, registering and unregistering it as a service within the OSGi framework.

This file defines an OSGi application used for smoke testing. It initializes an OSGi framework, installs and starts bundles, interacts with a published OSGi service, and then shuts down the framework.

This file contains JUnit 5 test methods designed to intentionally fail, serving as a test case for scenarios involving failed tests, possibly for replay mechanisms or error reporting within a smoke testing suite.

This directory is intended to contain documentation providing guidance and instructions on how to test the `dd-trace-java` project. Although currently empty, its purpose is to serve as a resource for developers looking for testing methodologies and practices.

This directory is designated for Groovy-based test files that would verify the functionality of interceptors related to CI visibility features within the `dd-trace-core` module. Its purpose is to house tests ensuring these components behave as expected.

This directory contains Groovy test code for the CI visibility feature within the `dd-trace-core` module. Specifically, it tests the data writer component responsible for sending CI visibility data to the Datadog intake API.

This directory is intended to hold test resources specifically for 'comp1' within the native loader component's test data. It likely serves as a placeholder for files that would be dynamically loaded or accessed during testing scenarios for 'comp1'. Its current emptiness suggests that no static resources are required at this level, or they are generated during test execution.

This file defines a custom Logback appender, `TestLogbackAppender`, designed to capture log events programmatically for testing purposes. It extends `AppenderBase` and routes captured logs to a `TestLogCollector`.

This document describes the various types of tests used in the project (e.g., unit, instrumented, integration, system tests) and provides instructions on how to run them, including details on forked and flaky tests.

This class serves as a data container for build module settings, primarily encapsulating a map of system properties. It is used to hold configuration specific to a build module within the CI visibility domain.

This file defines the `TestExecutionHistory` interface, which tracks the history and outcome of individual test executions, particularly concerning retries and failed test re-runs. It provides methods to register execution results and query details about the execution's final status and retry context.

This file defines an interface for policies that determine how test executions are handled, including whether their behavior should be altered or if failures should be suppressed, especially in the context of CI visibility.
This file provides a utility to resolve the appropriate Datadog Intake TrackType based on the application's configuration, primarily checking if CI visibility is enabled.

This file implements a mapper for serializing CI visibility test coverage data extracted from spans into a MsgPack format for transmission to the Datadog backend. It creates a payload for HTTP requests, specifically targeting version 2 of the CI Test Coverage API.

This class is responsible for mapping and serializing Datadog CI Visibility test cycle spans into a MessagePack format, including various test-related metadata and tags, for submission to the Datadog intake API.

This file provides functionality to retrieve CI (Continuous Integration) environment variables from a remote HTTP provider, handling network requests with retries and making them available to the application.

This test file verifies the functionality of the `CiEnvironmentVariables` class, specifically its ability to fetch environment variables from a remote source with retry logic. It uses a `MockWebServer` to simulate the remote endpoint and test various scenarios including successful retrieval, retries after initial failures, and handling of authentication.

This file defines a trace interceptor that collects telemetry for CI Visibility. It counts the number of spans in a completed trace and reports this as 'events enqueued for serialization' to a metric collector.
This class defines a periodic action specifically for collecting CI Visibility metrics. It provides the appropriate metric collector from the `InstrumentationBridge` for this purpose.

This directory contains Groovy test classes designed to validate the telemetry features of the CI visibility internal API. It ensures the correct functionality and data reporting for CI visibility metrics within the `dd-trace-java` project.

This file provides a no-operation (NoOp) implementation of the CiVisibilityMetricCollector interface. It acts as a placeholder when metric collection is disabled, ensuring that method calls have no effect and return empty values.
Defines an interface for enum-like tag values used in CI Visibility telemetry, providing methods for string representation, declaring class, and ordinal value.

This file defines a specialized class, `CiVisibilityMetricData`, for collecting and reporting CI Visibility-specific metrics. It extends `MetricCollector.Metric` and ensures metrics are properly formatted under the 'civisibility' namespace.

This file defines an enumeration of distribution metrics used for CI Visibility telemetry, capturing various performance and size aspects of CI/CD operations, Git interactions, and data transfers. It provides functionality to create telemetry data points with associated tags for these metrics.
This file defines an enumeration of count metrics used for Datadog CI Visibility telemetry, each associated with specific tags to provide additional context to the metric.
Defines an interface for collecting CI visibility telemetry metrics, allowing the addition of both distribution and count metrics.
This file defines an enum `BrowserDriver` to represent the type of browser driver used in a test case for CI visibility telemetry. It currently supports only Selenium.
This file defines an enum representing a telemetry tag indicating that early flake detection is enabled. It provides the specific string value for this tag to be used in telemetry data.

This file defines an enum `EventType` used for categorizing different types of test events (TEST, SUITE, MODULE, SESSION) within CI visibility telemetry. It provides a standardized string representation for these event types as tags.

This file defines an `AutoInjected` enum, which serves as a tag value for CI visibility telemetry. It specifically indicates whether the tracer was injected using CI-provider-specific auto-instrumentation.
Defines a telemetry tag `is_modified:true` to indicate that a test's definition has been modified, used within Datadog's CI Visibility feature.
This file defines an enum `GitShaMatch` used for telemetry tagging in Datadog's CI visibility. It indicates whether a Git SHA (commit hash) matched, with values `TRUE` or `FALSE`.
This file defines an enumeration (Endpoint) for different types of endpoints used in CI visibility telemetry, such as test cycles, code coverage, and LLM observations.

This file defines an enum `IsHeadless` used for telemetry tagging to indicate whether a test session is running in 'headless mode'. In headless mode, only child processes forked for tests are instrumented, not the parent build system.
This file defines a telemetry tag indicating whether flaky test retries are enabled. It provides a constant value representing the 'true' state of this feature for telemetry purposes.
This file defines an enum indicating whether a request body is compressed, used for telemetry tagging.

Defines an enumeration for common exit codes of shell command executions, used for tagging telemetry data. It provides predefined exit code values and a utility method to map integer exit codes to these enum values.

This enum defines different types of HTTP request errors, such as timeouts, network issues, or specific HTTP status code categories (4xx, 5xx). It provides methods to represent these errors as strings for telemetry tagging and to derive an error type from an HTTP response code.
This enum defines specific types of discrepancies that can occur with Git SHAs, used for tagging telemetry data within Datadog's CI visibility feature.
This file defines a telemetry tag (`impacted_tests_detection_enabled:true`) indicating that the impacted tests detection feature is enabled.
This enum represents whether code coverage is enabled based on a remote settings response, with 'TRUE' indicating it is enabled.
Defines a telemetry tag indicating that a test is quarantined. It provides a constant value 'is_quarantined:true' for use in CI visibility telemetry.
This file defines a telemetry tag indicating that 'fail-fast test order' is enabled. It's used to report a specific configuration state for CI visibility.
Defines a telemetry tag indicating that a test case is new, used for CI visibility metrics in Datadog tracing.

This file defines an enum for reasons why early flake detection might be aborted, intended for use in telemetry tagging within Datadog's CI Visibility module. It provides standardized string representations for these abort reasons like 'faulty' or 'slow'.
This file defines an enumeration of supported test framework instrumentations, used for tagging telemetry data to categorize tests by the framework they utilize.
This file defines an enum representing a telemetry tag value indicating whether the Intelligent Test Runner (ITR) feature is enabled based on remote settings.
Defines a telemetry tag value indicating that Intelligent Test Runner (ITR) skipping is enabled based on remote settings.

This enum defines different sources or providers of Git information that might be discrepant or conflicting within Datadog's CI visibility telemetry. It categorizes the origin of such conflicting data.
This file defines an enum `IsRetry` used as a telemetry tag. It indicates whether a test case is a retry, with its `TRUE` value representing 'is_retry:true'.

This file defines a telemetry tag `KnownTestsEnabled` that represents the state of known tests being enabled for CI visibility. It provides a string representation 'known_tests_enabled:true' for telemetry reporting.
This file defines a telemetry tag indicating whether an operation has failed after exhausting all retry attempts. It represents a boolean state for 'has_failed_all_retries' as 'true'.

This file defines an enum for specific HTTP status codes, primarily those indicating client-side errors, to be used for CI visibility telemetry tagging. It maps integer status codes to descriptive enum constants.

This file defines a telemetry tag enum `IsRum` used to indicate whether a test case is a RUM (Real User Monitoring) test within the CI visibility context.
This file defines an enum `RequireGit` that serves as a telemetry tag. It indicates whether the remote settings require waiting for a Git upload to finish.

This file defines an enum representing various Git command types, used for tagging telemetry data in Datadog's CI visibility feature. It helps categorize and track different Git operations performed during a CI/CD pipeline.
This file defines a telemetry tag indicating that test management is enabled. It is used within Datadog's CI visibility feature to report specific configuration states.
Defines an enum `RetryReason` that specifies various reasons for test retries, intended for use in telemetry tagging within the CI visibility feature.
This file defines an enum of supported CI providers, used for tagging and identifying the CI environment during test sessions for Datadog's CI visibility telemetry.
This file defines a telemetry tag 'is_disabled:true' for Datadog's CIVisibility feature, used to indicate that a specific component or functionality is disabled.
This enum defines specific reasons why a test might be skipped, such as by Test Impact Analysis (ITR) or due to being disabled, for use in telemetry tagging.
Defines an enumeration for different types of errors that can occur during code coverage collection, used for CI visibility telemetry tagging.
This file defines an enum (`HasCodeowner`) that represents whether a CODEOWNERS file was located during a test session. It is used as a telemetry tag for CI visibility to report this status.

This file defines a telemetry tag enum, `IsUnsupportedCI`, which indicates if a test session is running within an unsupported Continuous Integration (CI) environment. It signals that Datadog's CI visibility feature cannot extract full metadata from the environment.

This file defines telemetry tags used to indicate whether the 'failed test replay' feature is enabled or utilized within Datadog's CI Visibility. It provides distinct tags for settings, session, and individual test metrics.
This file defines an enum representing different code-coverage libraries (e.g., JaCoCo) used for tagging in Datadog's CI visibility telemetry.

This file defines a trace interceptor that filters completed traces, retaining only those originating from CI visibility tests. For these CI visibility test traces, it adds the library version tag to all spans within the trace.
This interceptor filters out CI Visibility-specific spans and tags that are not supported by the APM protocol, while also ensuring common CI Visibility tags are set on remaining test spans.

This file provides a bridge for non-test instrumentations to register listeners and receive notifications about test events, specifically before a test ends. It also allows retrieval of the current test context from the active span.

This file defines the `InstrumentationBridge` class, which serves as a central point for registering and creating CI Visibility test event handlers, build event handlers, and metric collectors. It provides an interface for different parts of the tracing system to interact with the CI Visibility features.

This interface defines a contract for handling various events that occur during a build process, such as the start and end of test sessions, build tasks, and test modules. It provides an API for tracking the lifecycle of builds and tests for CI visibility.

This file defines the `TestEventsHandler` interface, which specifies methods for reporting and managing test suite and individual test events within the Datadog CI Visibility system. It includes callbacks for test lifecycle events, execution policies, and skip reasons.

This directory contains Groovy-based test files for the internal Git-related API components of the Datadog Java tracer. Its purpose is to validate the functionality and integration of Git information within the `datadog.trace.api` package, specifically focusing on internal API aspects.

This directory is designated for Groovy-based tests verifying the internal API of Datadog's Java tracer, specifically focusing on Continuous Integration Visibility (CIVisibility) features related to Git integration. It would house test cases ensuring the correct functionality of Git-related aspects within the CIVisibility API.
Represents immutable information about a Git commit, including its SHA, author, committer, and full message, with utilities for combining and checking the completeness of commit data.

This interface defines a builder for constructing Git information (`GitInfo`), abstracting the process of retrieving Git details from a repository. It also includes methods for reporting telemetry related to Git provider discrepancies.

This class builds GitInfo by reading embedded `git.properties` files from the classpath, prioritizing specific locations typically generated by build tools like Spring Boot. It extracts repository URL, branch, commit details, and author/committer information.

Provides utility methods for parsing raw byte array content, specifically for extracting information from Git object data like commit messages, author/committer details, and numeric values. It is based on the JGit library's RawParseUtils.

This file defines the `PersonInfo` class, which represents a person's name, email, and an ISO8601 formatted date. It provides utilities for constructing, accessing, and combining this information, often used for identifying authors or committers in source control contexts.

This class provides a centralized mechanism for retrieving Git repository information, aggregating data from multiple builders, caching results, and handling potential discrepancies in Git commit SHAs from different sources.

This file provides utility methods for parsing, validating, and normalizing various Git-related data structures like branches, tags, commit SHAs, and author information, and also includes functionality for decompressing Git objects.

This file defines a class `CiVisibilityWellKnownTags` that stores and provides common CI Visibility tags (such as runtime details, OS info, and environment) as `UTF8BytesString` objects, optimizing them for efficient use within the Datadog trace library.
This file defines common string constants and tags used across Datadog's CI visibility features, including identifiers for test origins, browser drivers, and ITR/EFD specific tags.

This file defines the `TestIdentifier` class, which uniquely identifies a test case using its Fully Qualified Name (FQN) and optional parameters. It provides methods to access the suite, name, and parameters of a test.

This file defines an enum `LibraryCapability` that enumerates various CI visibility features (e.g., Test Impact Analysis, Early Flake Detection) that a library might support. Each capability has a corresponding tag and version for identification.
This file defines the `TestFQN` class, which represents a Fully Qualified Name used to uniquely identify a test case within a module by its suite and name.

This file defines the `TestMetadata` class, which serves as a data structure to encapsulate additional test metadata returned by a backend system, specifically indicating whether line code coverage information is missing.

This file defines a `Configurations` class that encapsulates various environment and runtime details, such as OS, runtime version, and a test bundle, along with custom key-value pairs. It serves as a data structure to hold configuration information for CI visibility.

This class is a data transfer object that holds information necessary to identify the source of a test definition, including its class, method, and potentially a distinct source method name. It helps track test origins, especially for frameworks where reflective method names might differ from source code names.

This enum defines supported programming languages and Gherkin, associating each with its file extension and whether it's considered non-code. It provides utility methods to retrieve a language based on a file name.

This file defines the `BuildSessionSettings` class, which encapsulates configuration options for code coverage reporting within a CI visibility build session. It specifies whether coverage reports should be uploaded and lists packages to include or exclude from coverage analysis.

This class represents a set of source files, categorized as either code or test, along with their corresponding compiled or processed destination files. It is used to encapsulate and manage different collections of source artifacts within a project.
This interface defines a generic context for tests, providing methods to store and retrieve test-related data, including test coverage information.
Defines the possible statuses for a test execution (pass, fail, skip) within the Datadog CI visibility tracing API.
This file defines the `TestDescriptor` class, which serves as a unique identifier for a test case by encapsulating its suite name, class, test name, parameters, and an optional qualifier.

This file defines the `TestSuiteDescriptor` class, a data structure used to uniquely identify a test suite within the Continuous Integration (CI) visibility system. It encapsulates the test suite's name and its corresponding Java class.
This file defines constant strings representing configuration keys for Datadog's CI Visibility feature and related testing functionalities in the Java tracer.

This interface defines a contract for managing the lifecycle and metadata of a test session within Datadog's CI visibility feature, allowing for tracking of overall test execution, errors, skips, and module-level activities.
This interface defines methods for managing the lifecycle and reporting of a test module within a CI visibility context, representing a logical group of test suites (e.g., a project module).
This interface defines the contract for managing a test suite, providing methods to set its properties, status (error, skipped), mark its end, and initiate individual test cases within it.

This file defines the `DDTest` interface, which represents an individual test case within the CI Visibility feature. It provides an API for setting test attributes like tags, error info, skip reasons, and marking the completion of a test's execution.

This file provides the primary API for integrating Continuous Integration (CI) visibility into Datadog traces, allowing users to start and manage test sessions. It uses a pluggable session factory for custom implementations of test session handling.

This file provides a no-operation (noop) implementation of the DDTestModule interface. It serves as a placeholder or default when CI visibility test module functionality is not enabled or required, preventing null pointer exceptions by doing nothing.
This file provides a no-operation (noop) implementation of the DDTestSession interface, serving as a null object when CIVisibility test session functionality is not enabled or required.

Provides a no-operation (noop) implementation of the DDTest interface, serving as a placeholder or default behavior when CI visibility is not enabled or applicable. It ensures method calls do nothing, preventing null pointer exceptions and offering a safe, empty implementation.

This file defines a `@Flaky` annotation used to mark test suites or individual tests that are known to be flaky, allowing them to be segregated and handled differently, particularly in CI environments.

Continuous Code Profiling.description: Identifies performance bottlenecks and code hotspots in production environments with low overhead. Continuously analyzes CPU and memory usage to pinpoint inefficient code for optimization.

files.description: This directory is intended to store non-code resources required by the profiling integration tests. It holds files such as configuration, data, or other assets that are placed on the classpath during test execution. These resources are crucial for setting up and running the profiling-related integration tests.
This file defines a JUnit 5 annotation, `@DisabledOnJ9`, which is used to conditionally disable tests (classes or methods) when executed on a J9 JVM.

This file contains integration tests for JFR-based profiling within the Datadog Java tracer. It verifies the continuous recording, processing, and uploading of profiling data to a mock profiling server.

This file provides utility methods for creating and managing Java processes with Datadog profiling configurations for integration smoke tests, including setting up JVM arguments and verifying process termination.

This JUnit Jupiter `ExecutionCondition` disables profiling-related tests when running on IBM J9 JVMs, except for specific supported Java versions. It ensures that tests requiring profiling context only execute on compatible J9 environments or non-J9 JVMs.

This file contains integration tests for the Datadog Java tracer's profiling capabilities, specifically verifying the collection and analysis of code hotspot data. It launches various test applications (reactive, batch, native library, generative stack traces) and inspects their Java Flight Recorder (JFR) dumps for expected CPU profiling events.

This file defines a utility class for simulating parallel processing workloads, where multiple worker threads execute a given task with simulated service times drawn from a normal distribution. It's used in profiling integration tests to generate activity.

This file is a smoke test application designed to profile and trace the performance of operations using native compression libraries (LZ4, Snappy) and the XXHash native hashing library. It demonstrates their usage within an OpenTracing context.

This Java application serves as a smoke test for Datadog's profiling and tracing features, simulating various workloads like CPU-intensive tasks, garbage collection, exceptions, concurrent execution, and deadlocks to verify their detection and reporting.

This file generates complex, recursive stack traces with varying depths and invocation methods (direct, MethodHandles, or lambdas) to be used in profiling and tracing integration tests. It also utilizes OpenTracing spans for each method call to simulate real-world tracing scenarios.

This file defines a `QueueProcessing` class that simulates a task queue and a pool of worker threads. It processes submitted tasks with simulated exponential service times, primarily used for profiling and integration tests.

This file defines a synthetic application used in profiling integration tests to simulate various workload patterns (reactive, batch, fanout) and generate code hotspots, along with OpenTracing spans for monitoring.
This file contains unit tests for the `RecordingInputStream` class, specifically verifying the functionality of its `isEmpty()` method under various conditions.

This file contains unit tests for the `ProfilingEnablement` logic, verifying how different configuration values (e.g., 'true', 'false', 'auto', numeric, null) are parsed and interpreted to determine the profiling enablement state.

This file contains unit tests for the `ProfilerFlareLogger` class, verifying its logging capabilities, capacity management, integration with the TracerFlare diagnostic report system, and thread safety.

This file contains JMH benchmarks to compare the performance of `HotSpotStackWalker` against `DefaultStackWalker` for collecting stack traces. It measures their efficiency when dealing with different stack depths and limits on collected elements.
This file contains JMH benchmarks to compare the performance of `JDK9StackWalker` with `DefaultStackWalker` for obtaining stack traces on JDK9+ environments.
Manages temporary file locations for profiling data, cleaning up orphaned temporary files from dead processes on startup, and ensuring cleanup on shutdown.
Defines an enumeration for different types of profiling recordings, such as continuous recording, used within Datadog's tracing library.
This file defines `RecordingInputStream`, a buffered input stream that provides a method to check if the stream is empty without permanently consuming any data.
Defines the ProfilingSnapshot interface, which represents a snapshot of profiling data, and an enum `Kind` to categorize the type of snapshot (e.g., periodic or on shutdown).

This file defines the `RecordingDataListener` interface, which is used to be notified when new profiling recording data becomes available. Implementations handle the processing and eventual release of this data.

This file provides a singleton logger for profiling events that captures log messages and stores them in memory up to a capacity limit. These stored logs can then be included in a support bundle (flare) for diagnostic purposes.
This file defines the `Timing` interface, used for profiling and reporting execution times or other timing-related metrics. It includes a `NoOp` implementation to disable timing when not needed.
This interface defines a timer mechanism for profiling or measuring the duration of specific operations, such as queueing. It includes a no-operation implementation for when timing is not required.

This file defines an abstract class `RecordingData` which serves as a platform-agnostic API for managing and retrieving recorded profiling data. It provides methods to access the data stream, release associated resources, and retrieve metadata such as the recording's name, start time, end time, and kind.
Defines an interface for retrieving profiling and tracing context information, including span IDs, root span IDs, operation names, and resource names.

This interface defines the contract for integrating different profiling systems with the Datadog trace context, providing lifecycle hooks and methods for encoding profiling data. It allows various profilers to interact with the tracing system consistently.
This file defines the `profiling` package, serving as an internal API communication and synchronization point between the tracer and profiler subsystems within Datadog's Java tracing library.

This interface defines methods for capturing profiling data related to queue operations. It allows recording details about a task, the scheduler, the queue itself, and its length for timing analysis within Datadog traces.
This file defines the `ProfilingContext` interface, which provides methods for setting and clearing context values to be appended to profiling data.
Defines the `ProfilingContextAttribute` interface, which likely serves as a marker interface for profiling-related context attributes, and provides a no-operation (NoOp) default implementation.

This file defines the public API for interacting with Datadog's profiling context within the tracing library. It provides methods to create profiling scopes and manage profiling-specific attributes for code instrumentation.

Defines an interface for a profiling scope within the Datadog Java tracer API. This scope extends AutoCloseable, allowing it to manage and release profiling-related resources automatically, and provides profiling context.

This enum defines different states for profiling enablement (e.g., enabled, disabled, auto, injected). It provides methods to parse configuration values and determine the active profiling state based on these settings.
Defines configuration keys and default values for Datadog's Java profiling features, allowing customization through system properties, environment variables, or config files.

Feature Flag Management.description: Integrates with Datadog's Feature Flagging service to control feature releases and conduct A/B testing safely. Tracks feature flag evaluations and their performance impact within application traces.

files.description: This directory is intended to store configuration files specifically used by the OpenFeature smoke tests within the Datadog Java tracer project. These configurations likely define OpenFeature settings or feature flag states for testing purposes.
This file defines the main entry point for a Spring Boot application, serving as a smoke test within the Datadog tracing project. It initializes and runs the Spring Boot application.

This Spring Boot REST controller provides an endpoint for evaluating OpenFeature flags. It exposes a POST API to resolve feature flags based on the provided flag key, variation type, default value, targeting key, and evaluation context attributes.

This Spring REST controller defines two endpoints: '/hello' which returns a simple greeting, and '/enableScheduling' which asynchronously enables a flag and waits for its status. It likely serves as a component in a smoke test or demonstration application.

This directory is designated for Groovy-based unit and integration tests for the `com.datadog.featureflag` package within the `feature-flagging-lib` module. Although currently empty, it defines the intended location for test files validating the feature flagging library's functionality.

This directory contains Groovy-based tests for the `feature-flagging-bootstrap` module within the Datadog Java tracer project. Its primary role is to validate the functionality and API of the feature flagging initialization components, ensuring correct behavior during tracer startup.
This file configures and provides an OpenFeature client bean within a Spring Boot application, using Datadog's OpenFeature provider for integration testing.

This file contains unit and integration tests for the `datadog.trace.api.openfeature.Provider` class. It verifies the functionality of the OpenFeature provider, including its initialization, state management, error handling, and flag evaluation mechanisms in conjunction with Datadog's feature flagging gateway.

This file contains unit tests for the `DDEvaluator` class, which implements OpenFeature evaluations based on Datadog's feature flagging system. It verifies various evaluation scenarios, including value mapping, context flattening, and error handling.

This file defines a generic `TestCase` utility class for building and managing feature flag evaluation test scenarios, including the flag's name, default value, evaluation context, and expected results. It is used to streamline the creation of tests for OpenFeature integrations.

This file defines the Datadog-specific implementation of an OpenFeature Provider, enabling applications to interact with Datadog's feature flagging system to evaluate and retrieve feature flag values. It integrates with an internal `Evaluator` to handle the actual flag resolution and lifecycle events.
Defines the activation states for a product within the Datadog tracing library, indicating whether it's fully enabled, fully disabled, or enabled but currently inactive.

This file defines configuration constants specifically related to feature flagging within the Datadog trace API. It provides keys like `FLAGGING_PROVIDER_ENABLED` to control feature flagging functionality.
This file defines the `Variant` class, which represents a specific variant or configuration of a feature flag, identified by a unique key.

This file defines the `Subject` class, which encapsulates an entity's unique identifier and a map of its associated attributes. It is typically used to represent a subject for feature flag evaluation.
This file defines the `Environment` class, which is a simple data structure used to represent an environment within the feature flagging system. It holds the name of the environment.

This file defines an enumeration of operators used for evaluating conditions within a feature flagging or unified configuration system. It lists various comparison and matching operators like LT, GT, MATCHES, and ONE_OF.
Defines the `Variant` class, representing a key-value pair for a specific variation within a feature flag system.

This file defines the `Allocation` class, a data structure used in Datadog's feature flagging system. It encapsulates the configuration for a feature flag, including its identifier, associated rules, validity period, and how traffic should be split.
Defines the 'Shard' class, which represents a segment or division used in a feature flagging system, including a salt for hashing, specific ranges, and the total number of shards.
This file defines the `Rule` class, which represents a rule within a feature flagging system. A rule consists of a list of conditions that determine its activation or application.
This file defines the `ValueType` enum, which specifies the supported data types for values used in the Universal Feature Control (UFC) system's feature flags.

This file defines the `Flag` data class, representing the configuration of a feature flag within Datadog's Unified Feature Control (UFC) system. It encapsulates details like the flag's key, its enabled status, variation type, available variations, and allocation rules.
This class defines a data structure representing a single condition for a feature flag, including an operator, an attribute, and a value to evaluate against.
Defines a simple data structure to represent a numerical range, characterized by a start and an end integer. This class is likely used within a feature flagging system to define segments or shards.

This class defines a 'Split' used in feature flagging, representing a specific variation and the conditions (shards) that determine its application. It encapsulates the data needed to evaluate and apply a particular feature flag variation.

This file defines the `ServerConfiguration` class, which serves as a data model for the complete feature flag configuration received from a server. It encapsulates metadata like creation timestamp, format, environment details, and a map of individual feature flags.

This file defines the `Evaluator` interface, which specifies methods for initializing, shutting down, and evaluating feature flags within the Datadog OpenFeature API. It provides a contract for components responsible for feature flag evaluation.

This file implements the OpenFeature `Evaluator` interface for Datadog's feature flagging API, providing logic to evaluate feature flags based on server configurations, context, rules, and sharding to determine the appropriate flag variant.
This file defines the `RemoteConfigService` interface, which specifies methods for initializing and closing a service responsible for managing remote configurations, likely related to feature flags.

This file implements a service responsible for fetching and processing remote feature flag configurations from the Datadog remote configuration system, then dispatching them to the feature flagging gateway for evaluation.

This file defines a static gateway for Datadog's feature flagging system, allowing components to register as listeners for feature flag configuration updates and exposure events, and to dispatch these events.
This file implements the `ExposureWriter` interface, responsible for collecting, deduplicating, and periodically sending feature flag exposure events to the Datadog backend (Event Platform).
This file defines an interface for a component responsible for asynchronously sending feature flag exposure events to the Datadog Event Proxy (EVP).

Implements an LRU (Least Recently Used) cache for storing feature flag exposure events. It's used within the feature flagging library to manage and deduplicate exposure events, ensuring that only new or changed events are processed.

This interface defines a cache for feature flag exposure events, allowing storage and retrieval of exposure details based on flag and subject. It includes nested `Key` and `Value` classes for identifying and storing relevant exposure information.
Defines a simple data structure, 'Flag', to represent a feature flag identified by its key. It is used within the Datadog Java tracer's feature flagging exposure mechanism.
This file defines a simple data class `Allocation` used in the context of feature flagging exposure. It holds a single string `key` to identify a specific allocation.
This class encapsulates a request for reporting feature flag exposures, including a list of exposure events and contextual information.

This file defines the `ExposureEvent` class, which serves as a data container to represent a single instance of a feature flag exposure. It captures essential details such as the timestamp, the feature flag, its variant, allocation information, and the subject involved.

Log & Trace Correlation.description: Automatically injects trace and span IDs into application logs across various logging frameworks. This enables seamless correlation between logs and distributed traces, allowing users to navigate from a log entry to the full request trace.

files.description: This directory is designated to hold non-code resources, such as configuration files, for the log injection smoke tests within the Datadog Java tracer project. It supports the setup and execution of tests verifying log injection functionality.

This directory is part of the Datadog Java tracer's smoke test suite. It specifically contains Groovy-based test files for validating the log injection feature. These tests ensure that log injection works correctly within a smoke test environment.
This file implements a smoke test application demonstrating log injection with Log4j 1.x. It extends a base application and logs messages using Log4j's `info` level.
This file defines a smoke test application that uses Flogger for logging, extending a base application to demonstrate and test Datadog's log injection capabilities with the Flogger framework.

This file implements a smoke test interface using Java Util Logging (JUL) to demonstrate log injection capabilities within the Datadog tracer for Java applications. It defines a `doLog` method that uses `java.util.logging.Logger` to output messages.

This file is a smoke test application that uses Jakarta Commons Logging (JCL) to demonstrate and verify log injection functionality within a Datadog tracing environment.

This abstract base class is used in smoke tests to verify the dynamic behavior of log injection within a traced application. It performs logging at various stages of traced methods and checks if log injection can be enabled and disabled during runtime.

This file defines a JAX-RS resource for a Quarkus native smoke test, demonstrating Datadog tracing integration by logging current trace and span IDs using SLF4J.

This file defines a Quarkus REST endpoint (`/hello-slf4j`) that uses SLF4J for logging and demonstrates Datadog trace and span ID injection into SLF4J debug logs, serving as a smoke test for tracing integration.
This Quarkus JAX-RS resource demonstrates Datadog tracing integration with JBoss Logging by logging trace and span IDs within a simple endpoint, likely for smoke testing.

This directory contains Groovy-based unit and integration tests for the correlation ID injection feature within the OpenTracing module of the Datadog Java tracer. Its purpose is to ensure the correct functionality and integration of correlation ID propagation.
This interface defines methods for handling log events within the context of an `AgentSpan`, providing an abstraction layer for how logs are processed and associated with a trace span.
This file provides an implementation to inject Datadog trace and span correlation IDs into Log4j2's ThreadContext for logging purposes, ensuring logs are correlated with traces.

This file defines a correlation ID injector that inserts Datadog trace and span identifiers into the SLF4J Mapped Diagnostic Context (MDC) for logging correlation.

This abstract class provides a base for injecting correlation IDs into traces by listening to scope activation and closure events from the internal tracer. Subclasses implement the specific logic for correlation ID injection at these points.

This utility class dynamically registers correlation ID injectors for common logging frameworks like Log4j, Log4j2, and SLF4J/Logback. It detects which logging frameworks are present at runtime and enables the appropriate injector to propagate tracing correlation IDs into application logs.

This file provides an internal API for registering and executing callbacks when a global tracer is installed or becomes available, without exposing this mechanism to end-users. It ensures certain functionalities, like MDC log injection, can react to the tracer's presence.
This file provides a utility class to access active Datadog trace and span IDs, along with their respective keys, primarily for integration with MDC frameworks for logging.

This directory is intended for Groovy-based integration or unit tests within the `dd-trace-java` project. Specifically, it targets the `log` component of the `telemetry` module, verifying its functionality for collecting and reporting logging-related telemetry data.
