This directory contains Groovy test files for internal configuration providers within the `bootstrap` module of the Datadog Java tracer. These tests validate the functionality and behavior of how the tracer retrieves and applies its internal configurations during startup.
This file defines an interface for walking and filtering stack traces, specifically to exclude elements originating from the `dd-trace-java` agent itself.
This file provides utilities for collecting diagnostic information (reports) from various components and packaging them into a ZIP file, typically for generating support 'flares'.

This file implements a poller that listens for remote configuration updates from the agent to trigger and manage 'flare' actions, such as preparing for a flare by adjusting log levels or submitting a flare based on agent tasks.

This service collects and packages diagnostic information (like configurations, runtime details, and thread dumps) into a ZIP file, either for local "triage reports" or for submission to a remote "tracer flare" endpoint.

This file implements a `Socket` subclass that allows Java applications to use Unix Domain Sockets (UDS) as if they were standard TCP sockets, leveraging Java 16's built-in UDS support. It 'tunnels' TCP-like communication over a UDS for higher fidelity impersonation.

This file contains unit tests for the `TunnelingJdkSocket` class, verifying its functionality including connection/closure, input/output stream behavior, socket options like timeouts and buffer sizes, and file descriptor management.

This class provides an asynchronous message publisher that uses a cached thread pool to send messages to subscribers in a non-blocking manner. It extends `PublisherSupport` and handles the lifecycle of the executor service.

This file defines a `FlushingBuffer` class that accumulates data into an internal `ByteBuffer` and groups it into messages. It provides methods to write various data types and to flush the accumulated messages to a consumer, resetting itself for subsequent use.

This class serves as a central codec for serialization, dynamically mapping Java types to their corresponding `ValueWriter` implementations to handle the writing of various data structures and primitives to a `Writable` packer.

This factory class is responsible for creating and providing the appropriate metrics aggregator instance based on the tracer metrics configuration, enabling or disabling metric collection accordingly.
This interface defines a Sink for metrics, enabling the consumption of byte buffers and the registration of event listeners.

This file provides a 'no-operation' (no-op) implementation of the MetricsAggregator interface. It serves as a placeholder when metrics aggregation is not enabled or desired, performing no actions for any of its methods.

This class is responsible for continuously collecting, aggregating, and periodically reporting metrics. It processes incoming metric batches, aggregates them, and writes the accumulated metrics using a MetricWriter.
Defines an interface for items processed by an inbox, including abstract and concrete classes for asynchronous stop and report signals that manage their completion state.

This file implements a sink for sending metrics data to a Datadog agent over HTTP using OkHttp, handling both synchronous and asynchronous sending based on network performance and buffering requests when the agent is slow to respond.

This file implements a `MetricWriter` that serializes metric data into MessagePack format. It gathers common tags and aggregated metric values, writes them to a buffer, and then sends the serialized data to a specified sink.

This file defines the `DistributionSeries` class, a data model for representing a series of distribution metrics within Datadog's telemetry API. It encapsulates a metric name, data points, associated tags, and other metadata like commonality and namespace.

This file contains unit tests for the `TagMap.Ledger` class, verifying its functionality for building mutable and immutable `TagMap` instances, handling various data types, removals, and state resets.

This file contains fuzz tests for the `OptimizedTagMap` class, ensuring its robustness and correctness under various map manipulation operations like put, remove, and putAll. It includes tests to reproduce previously identified failing scenarios.

This file contains unit tests for the `OptimizedTagMap.BucketGroup` class, verifying its functionality related to creating, inserting, replacing, and removing tag entries, as well as operations involving chained bucket groups.

This file contains unit tests for the `TagsHelper` utility class. It verifies that the `TagsHelper` correctly sanitizes, normalizes, limits the length of, and concatenates tags according to defined rules.

This directory is designated for Groovy-based test files that validate the internal API's metrics functionality within the Datadog Java tracer project. It specifically targets testing components related to the `datadog.trace.api.metrics` package.

This file defines a specialized, high-performance hash map interface (`TagMap`) optimized for small, immutable collections, efficient copying, minimal memory footprint, and storing primitive values without boxing.
This file defines the `CoreCounter` interface, specifying methods for a basic counter metric, including getting its name, current value, and resetting its value.
This file defines configuration keys (constants) for JMX Fetch settings within the Datadog Java Agent. These keys are used to configure JMX metric collection and related behaviors.

This file provides a 'no-operation' implementation of the Histogram interface, where all methods perform no action or return default/empty values. It serves as a placeholder or default histogram that does nothing.
Provides a no-operation (dummy) implementation of the Monitoring interface, used when monitoring is disabled or not required.
Provides a no-operation implementation of the Counter interface, used when metrics collection is disabled or not needed, to prevent null pointer exceptions and simplify code.
Defines the Counter interface for incrementing metric values. It provides methods for general increments and specifically for error counts associated with a cause.

This file defines the `Monitoring` interface, which provides a standard API for creating monitoring instruments such as timers and counters. It is a core component of the metrics API for Datadog's Java tracing library.
Defines an abstract class for managing the lifecycle of a recording or measurement operation, including starting, stopping, resetting, and flushing collected data.

Provides a no-operation (null object) implementation of the Recording interface, allowing calls to its methods without performing any actual metric recording. This is typically used as a default or placeholder when metrics collection is disabled or not configured.

This file defines a factory interface and a registration mechanism for providing various `Histogram` implementations within the Datadog metrics API. It acts as an entry point for external libraries to plug in their specific histogram factories.

Defines the `Histogram` interface, which specifies a contract for data structures used to track the distribution of observed values. It provides methods for adding values, retrieving statistical properties like count, min, max, and quantiles, and accessing bin information.
This factory provides 'no-operation' (noop) histogram instances, which perform no metric collection or processing.
This file defines the `StatsDClient` interface, which provides a contract for sending various metrics (counters, gauges, histograms, distributions), service checks, and events to a StatsD server.

This file provides a no-operation (No-Op) implementation of the StatsDClient interface. It serves as a placeholder when metrics collection is disabled, preventing `NullPointerException`s without performing any actual metric reporting.

This file defines an interface for managing and providing StatsDClient instances. It specifies methods to obtain a StatsDClient with various configuration options, including host, port, namespace, tags, and aggregation settings.

This file provides a wrapper around the DDSketch library, adapting it to the `Histogram` interface for use in Datadog's metrics instrumentation. It forwards all `Histogram` operations to an underlying DDSketch instance.

This file defines a `ThreadLocalRecording` class which acts as a proxy for a `Recording` object stored in a `ThreadLocal`. It delegates all recording operations (start, reset, stop, flush) to the thread-specific `Recording` instance.

This file provides the concrete implementation of the `Monitoring` interface, creating various metric types like timers and counters using a StatsD client. It manages the creation of these monitoring instruments, often with a configurable flush interval for timing metrics.
This file implements a `Timer` that records durations into a histogram. It periodically flushes statistical aggregates (like p50, p99, and max) from the histogram to a StatsD client as gauge metrics.
This file implements a `Counter` interface, reporting metric increments to a StatsD client. It provides methods for general increments and specialized error count increments with cause-specific tags.
Provides utility methods for internal use within the metrics library, specifically for merging arrays of tags.

This file provides a factory for creating different types of histograms based on the DDSketch algorithm, including standard, logarithmic, and explicitly binned histograms, for use within the Datadog metrics implementation.

This file defines a `StatsDClient` implementation that logs all StatsD-formatted metrics, events, and service checks to a logger instead of sending them over a network, useful for debugging or monitoring logged output.

This directory contains Groovy test files for the StatsD API within the `dd-trace-java` metrics library. It is responsible for verifying the correct functionality and integration of the StatsD client implementation.

This directory is designated for Groovy-based unit and integration tests related to the StatsD implementation within the `metrics-lib` component of the Datadog Java tracer. It verifies the functionality and correctness of how StatsD metrics are handled and reported by the library.
This file provides static information about the Java runtime environment and loads the version string for the dd-trace-core component from a resource file, making it accessible programmatically.

This file contains unit tests for the `DependencyService`, verifying its ability to correctly identify and extract dependency metadata from JARs located within various virtual file system constructs, such as JBoss VFS mounts and ZIP files.
This file defines a periodic action that collects determined dependencies from a `DependencyService` and reports them to the `TelemetryService`.

This class is a `ClassFileTransformer` responsible for observing loaded classes and extracting their source locations (JARs or directories) from their `ProtectionDomain` to report them as dependencies to a `DependencyService`.
This file contains a utility class responsible for resolving and extracting dependency information from JAR files, including nested JARs within archives, given a URI.

Manages a queue of URIs representing potential dependencies within a Java application, filtering duplicates and irrelevant files before they are resolved into structured dependency objects, and enforcing a configurable queue size limit.

This file defines the `Dependency` class, representing a software dependency with its name, version, source, and hash. It provides methods to extract dependency information from JAR files, either by parsing Maven `pom.properties` or by guessing details from JAR manifests and file names, including computing a SHA-1 hash of the JAR content.
This class provides utility methods for interacting with JBoss's Virtual File System (VFS) via reflection to extract physical file paths, particularly for JARs, from JBoss VFS URLs.
This file provides utility methods for reading and extracting metadata (such as POM properties and Manifest attributes) from JAR files, including those nested within other JARs.
This file provides static utility methods to retrieve detailed host and operating system information, such as hostname, OS name, version, kernel details, and architecture.
This class detects if the application is running within an AWS Lambda serverless environment and checks for the presence of the Datadog agent extension.
This file defines an enum called `TriState` which represents a three-valued logic (true, false, or unknown). It assigns integer values to these states, primarily for metrics serialization purposes.

This directory contains Groovy-based test code for the metric collection and reporting components of the `telemetry` module within the Datadog Java tracer. Its purpose is to ensure the correct functionality and reliability of the telemetry metric implementation. These tests specifically verify the behavior of various metric types and their data handling.

This directory contains resources, such as configuration or data files, specifically utilized by the Java Microbenchmark Harness (JMH) for performance testing the telemetry components of the Datadog Java tracing library. Its role is to provide necessary external assets for these benchmarks to accurately measure telemetry-related performance.

This file defines a unified interface for various telemetry event sources, such as configuration changes, integrations, metrics, and logs. It includes a queue-based implementation for collecting and dispatching these events.

This file defines a class that collects configuration settings, dependencies, and integrations, and provides a snapshot of this data for telemetry purposes, specifically for extended heartbeat events.

This enum defines the different types of telemetry requests or events that can be sent from a Datadog Java application, such as application lifecycle events, configuration changes, metrics, logs, and distributions.

This file defines the `Metric` data model class used in Datadog's telemetry API. It encapsulates properties like metric name, type (gauge, rate, count), points, tags, and namespace for reporting metrics.

This file defines a telemetry action that periodically collects product changes from a collector and reports them to the telemetry service. It ensures that any changes in product configuration or state are sent as part of the application's telemetry data.

This file defines a periodic action that provides the `ConfigInversionMetricCollectorImpl`. It integrates the collection of configuration inversion metrics into the telemetry's periodic action system for the Datadog Java tracer.
This file defines a periodic action responsible for collecting core telemetry metrics for the Datadog Java tracer, providing an instance of the CoreMetricCollector.

This file defines a periodic action that collects the state of various integrations from a collector and reports them to the TelemetryService. It ensures that the telemetry system is updated with which integrations are enabled or disabled.
This file provides a lightweight helper class for testing the Config Inversion telemetry metric collection, specifically for simulating and emitting metrics for 'unknown' environment variables.

This file defines a singleton class for collecting and reporting metrics related to the propagation of 'baggage' (context/metadata) in distributed tracing. It tracks operations like baggage extraction, injection, and truncation, providing counters for these events.

This file provides the default implementation of `SpanMetricRegistry`, acting as a central registry to manage and retrieve `SpanMetrics` instances for various instrumentation names within the Datadog Java tracer.
Defines an enum `LoginEvent` to categorize different login-related events, such as success, failure, or sign-up, for telemetry purposes.

This file defines an interface for collecting and draining telemetry metrics, including their data structures for standard metrics and distribution series points, to be reported to a telemetry system.

This file defines an implementation for collecting telemetry metrics related to configuration inversion. It tracks undocumented or untracked configuration usage and queues these metrics for later reporting.
Defines an enum for different versions of a login mechanism, specifically V1, V2, and an automatic detection option, each associated with a string tag.

This class is responsible for collecting and draining core metrics, such as span and baggage-related metrics, for telemetry purposes. It aggregates these metrics and makes them available for reporting.

This file defines a singleton class for collecting and draining `ProductChange` events for telemetry purposes. It provides methods to add new product changes to an internal queue and retrieve all collected changes in a batch.

This class collects and aggregates unique log messages, limiting the capacity, to be sent as telemetry data. It allows adding new log entries and draining all collected messages along with their occurrence counts.

This file implements a singleton class responsible for collecting and reporting the enabled/disabled status of various integrations for telemetry purposes. It provides methods to update integration statuses and to drain all pending updates as a map of integration names to their latest enabled state.

This file defines a `ProductChange` class, along with an inner `ProductType` enum, to represent and track changes in the enabled/disabled state of various product types (e.g., appsec, profiler) for telemetry purposes.

This file provides a no-operation (NOOP) implementation of the `ConfigInversionMetricCollector` interface. It serves as a default fallback when the actual metric collector is not available, logging debug messages instead of collecting metrics.

An interface for collecting telemetry metrics related to OpenTelemetry environment variables, specifically tracking cases where variables are hidden, invalid, or unsupported when mapped to Datadog configurations.
Provides a static access point and registration mechanism for the `ConfigInversionMetricCollector` instance, allowing a default no-operation implementation to be replaced at runtime.
This interface defines a collector for metrics related to configuration settings, specifically for recording when undocumented environment variables are used to configure a given setting.
This file provides a static provider for a singleton instance of `OtelEnvMetricCollector`, allowing it to be registered and retrieved throughout the application.

This file defines the DDEvpProxyApi class, which is responsible for sending serialized trace data to a Datadog Intake endpoint through an EVP (Environment Variable Proxy) URL, handling network communication, retries, and metrics.

This class dynamically discovers and provides the appropriate remote mapper for different telemetry tracks (e.g., CI Test Cycles, CI Test Coverage, LLM Observability) destined for the Datadog Intake API, based on the `TrackType`.

This directory is designated for integration tests specifically for the `telemetry` component of the Datadog Java tracer. These tests, written in Groovy, are crucial for verifying the end-to-end functionality and correct behavior of telemetry data collection and reporting.

This directory is designated for Groovy-based test files that validate the functionality and behavior of the telemetry endpoint within the Datadog Java tracer. It specifically covers tests related to how telemetry data is collected and transmitted.

This file defines the `EventSink` interface, which provides a unified mechanism for buffering and managing various telemetry events (e.g., config changes, integrations, metrics, logs) before they are sent. It includes a NOOP implementation to discard events when necessary.

This file defines the `TelemetryClient` class, responsible for building and sending HTTP requests containing telemetry data to either a Datadog Agent or directly to the Datadog intake API, handling retries and errors.

This file defines a `Runnable` class that serves as a background thread for periodically collecting and sending telemetry data (metrics, configurations, heartbeats, and lifecycle events) to a telemetry service.

This file defines a `BufferedEvents` class that acts as both an event source and sink, storing various types of telemetry events (e.g., config changes, integrations, metrics, dependencies) in memory. It buffers these events to be processed or sent in subsequent telemetry requests or for metric calculations.

This file defines a `RequestBody` for Datadog telemetry, responsible for serializing various telemetry data types (metrics, logs, configurations, etc.) into a JSON format suitable for transmission to the Datadog Agent.

This file initializes, configures, and manages the lifecycle of the Datadog Telemetry system. It orchestrates the collection and submission of various telemetry data points (metrics, dependencies, logs, etc.) to the Datadog agent or intake in a dedicated thread.

This file defines the `TelemetryService` class, which is responsible for collecting, buffering, and sending various types of telemetry data (configurations, integrations, dependencies, metrics, logs, etc.) from the Java agent to a telemetry intake.

This file defines the `TelemetryRequest` class, which is responsible for building and populating an HTTP request with various telemetry data (e.g., configurations, metrics, logs, dependencies, product changes) collected from an `EventSource` for submission to a telemetry endpoint, while managing message size limits.

An abstract class that defines a periodic action for collecting, converting, and sending metrics and distribution series from a MetricCollector to the TelemetryService. It handles the aggregation and transformation of raw metric data into a telemetry-compatible format.

This class defines a periodic action to collect endpoint telemetry data from an EndpointCollector and submit it to the TelemetryService, re-queueing any endpoints that fail to be added for later processing.

This file defines an enumeration `TrackType` used to categorize different types of data or features being tracked (e.g., CI tests, LLM observability), associating each type with a specific API endpoint.
Defines a custom exception `LibraryLoadException` thrown when there are issues resolving or loading native libraries using `NativeLoader`.
This file defines an interface for strategies used to locate and resolve native libraries based on a given platform specification and library name.

This file defines the `LibFile` class, which represents a resolved native library and manages its loading into the JVM, including handling preloaded libraries, regular files, and temporary files that may require cleanup.
This class wraps a PathLocator to facilitate native library look-up, storing the first encountered exception during location attempts for later deferred throwing as a LibraryLoadException.
Provides utility methods for generating platform-specific file paths and names for native libraries, considering OS, architecture, and libc details.

This file defines a no-operation (NOP) implementation of a `LibraryLoadingListener`. It serves as a placeholder or default listener that performs no actions itself, but can be safely joined with other listeners to form a composite.
This file implements a `LibraryResolver` that finds native libraries by searching in nested directories structured by operating system, architecture, and libc, with fallbacks to less specific paths.
A test utility class that implements `PathLocator` to capture and assert the sequence of `locate` calls made by a `LibraryResolver`, simulating path resolution behavior for testing purposes.

This file defines a test utility that implements the `LibraryLoadingListener` interface, with all its callback methods designed to throw a `RuntimeException`. Its purpose is likely to test error handling or specific exception scenarios within library loading processes.

This file contains unit tests for the `PathLocators` class, specifically verifying the correct implementation of `equals` and `hashCode` methods for various `PathLocator` types, primarily for code coverage purposes.

This file contains unit tests for `IntrospectPlatformSpec`, verifying that it correctly identifies the operating system, architecture, and musl libc status based on the `OperatingSystem` utility class.

This file contains unit tests for the `NestedDirLibraryResolver`, verifying its ability to correctly resolve native library paths for different operating systems, architectures, and C standard library variants, including fallback mechanisms.

This file contains unit tests for the `PathUtils` class, which is responsible for generating platform-specific file names, prefixes, extensions, and path components for native libraries based on operating system, architecture, and libc details.

This file contains unit tests for the `NativeLoader` class, verifying its functionality for loading native libraries. It covers various scenarios such as preloading, platform-specific loading, error handling during resolution and loading, and loading from different directory structures.

This file contains unit tests for the PlatformSpec class, verifying its ability to correctly identify various operating systems (Mac, Linux, Windows, unknown) and processor architectures (ARM32, ARM64, X86_32, X86_64, unknown).

Real User Monitoring (RUM) Integration.description: Correlates backend performance with frontend user experience by linking server-side traces to Real User Monitoring (RUM) browser sessions. Provides a complete view of the user journey from client to database.

files.description: This directory is intended to contain JavaServer Pages (JSP) files for the Spring Boot JPA smoke test web application. As a `WEB-INF/jsp` location, it serves as the repository for server-side view templates that render dynamic web content for the application's user interface.
This servlet serves an XML response, primarily used for testing Real User Monitoring (RUM) injection scenarios in a web application.
This file defines an asynchronous Java servlet that serves a basic HTML page after a 2-second delay. It is likely used for smoke testing of Real User Monitoring (RUM) in a Tomcat 9 environment.
This file defines a simple Java HttpServlet that serves a static HTML page. It's used in RUM smoke tests for Tomcat 9 to provide a basic web page for monitoring.
This file initializes and starts an embedded Tomcat 9 server, registering various servlets to serve different content, likely for smoke testing Datadog RUM integration.

This directory is designated for Groovy-based smoke tests that validate the Real User Monitoring (RUM) functionality of the `dd-trace-java` agent. Specifically, these tests target applications deployed within a Tomcat 9 environment.
This file sets up and starts an embedded Tomcat server, configuring multiple servlets (HTML, HTML Async, XML) to serve as a test application for RUM (Real User Monitoring) smoke tests.
This Java servlet demonstrates an asynchronous HTTP GET request, serving a simple HTML page after a 2-second delay using `AsyncContext` and a `Timer`.
This file defines a Java servlet that serves a simple HTML page. It is used as part of a smoke test for Real User Monitoring (RUM) within a Tomcat 11 environment.
This file defines a Java servlet that serves a static XML response, primarily used for testing Real User Monitoring (RUM) injection within a Datadog smoke test environment on Tomcat 11.

This directory contains the Groovy-based smoke tests specifically designed for the Real User Monitoring (RUM) integration with Tomcat 11 within the `dd-trace-java` project. It ensures that the RUM tracing functionality operates correctly in a Tomcat 11 environment.

This servlet serves an XML response, specifically for testing RUM (Real User Monitoring) injection within a Tomcat 10 environment. It outputs a simple XML structure containing a success status and a test message.

This file defines an asynchronous Java servlet for Tomcat 10 that responds with a simple HTML page after a 2-second delay. It is likely used for RUM smoke tests to demonstrate asynchronous request handling and HTML content serving.

This file sets up and starts an embedded Tomcat 10 server, registering various servlets (HTML, async HTML, XML). It likely serves as a smoke test or demonstration for a RUM (Real User Monitoring) integration within a Java application.
This file defines a basic Java HttpServlet that serves a simple HTML page. It's used within Datadog's RUM smoke tests for Tomcat 10 to verify web server and tracing integration.

This directory contains Groovy-based smoke tests for Datadog's Real User Monitoring (RUM) feature, specifically designed for applications deployed on Tomcat 10. These tests verify the basic functionality and integration of the dd-trace-java agent in a Tomcat 10 environment for RUM purposes.

This directory contains Groovy-based smoke tests for the Real User Monitoring (RUM) feature of the Datadog Java tracer. These tests are specifically designed to run against and validate functionality on a WildFly 15 application server environment. Its purpose is to ensure critical RUM functionalities are working correctly in a specific server configuration.

This directory is intended to contain JavaServer Pages (JSPs) for a web application used in the RUM (Real User Monitoring) smoke tests. It is part of a WAR file, which in turn is part of an EAR deployment for WildFly 15, within the Datadog Java tracer repository.

This directory serves as the standard container for web application resources and configuration that are not directly accessible to clients. Within this RUM smoke test application for WildFly 15, it would typically hold the `web.xml` deployment descriptor, private server-side classes, and library JARs, defining the application's structure and behavior.
This file defines a Java Servlet, `HtmlServlet`, which handles HTTP GET requests for the `/html` endpoint. It serves as a basic web component within the application.

This Servlet Filter is used in RUM smoke tests on WildFly to conditionally forward requests to a JSP page (`/jsp/html.jsp`) or allow them to continue through the filter chain, primarily for testing purposes.

This file defines a Java Servlet that serves a fixed XML response at the '/xml' endpoint. It is part of the RUM smoke tests, likely used to verify XML handling or RUM integration within a WildFly application.

This directory is intended to contain Groovy source code for smoke tests specifically targeting Real User Monitoring (RUM) functionalities within the `dd-trace-java` project. It ensures basic RUM feature integration and functionality are validated.

This directory contains Groovy-based test code for the Real User Monitoring (RUM) functionality within the `telemetry` module of the `dd-trace-java` project. It ensures the correct behavior and integration of RUM telemetry features.

This directory contains Groovy test sources for the internal API components related to Real User Monitoring (RUM) within the Datadog Java tracer. Its purpose is to validate the RUM internal API's functionality and ensure its stability.

This file defines a periodic action that collects RUM (Real User Monitoring) telemetry metrics and distributions, converts them to the appropriate telemetry API format, and sends them to the TelemetryService.
This class collects and stores telemetry metrics and distributions related to Real User Monitoring (RUM) injection events, preparing them for reporting to the Datadog telemetry intake system.

This interface defines methods for collecting and reporting telemetry metrics related to the injection of Real User Monitoring (RUM) code into web responses. It tracks events such as injection success/failure, initialization, and performance metrics like response size and injection time.

This file contains unit tests for the `RumInjectorConfig` class, verifying its ability to correctly process various valid and invalid RUM configuration parameters and generate the expected JSON payload.
This enum defines and manages different modes for collecting and tracking user IDs within the application, such as identification, anonymization, disabled, or SDK-based collection.

Defines an enum `UserEventTrackingMode` to control the level of user event tracking (disabled, safe, extended) within the Datadog trace API. It provides methods to convert string values to these tracking modes.
This class is responsible for injecting a Real User Monitoring (RUM) JavaScript snippet into HTML responses, typically before the </head> tag, and managing related telemetry.

This class defines and validates the configuration for injecting Datadog Real User Monitoring (RUM) into a web application. It generates a JavaScript snippet that initializes the RUM browser agent with the specified settings.
Defines constant keys for various Real User Monitoring (RUM) configuration properties within the Datadog tracing library.

Dynamic Agent Configuration.description: Allows for dynamic management of agent configurations without requiring restarts or redeployments. Enables operators to update tracing settings, sampling rules, and feature enablement remotely across a fleet of applications.

files.description: This directory is intended to house Groovy-based smoke tests that verify the functionality of dynamic configuration features within the Datadog Java tracer. It serves as the designated location for these specific integration tests.

This file implements a poller for remote configuration of Datadog APM tracing settings, including sampling rules, feature flags, and logging levels, applying dynamic updates to the tracer's configuration.

This directory is designated for Groovy-based unit and integration tests specifically targeting the state management components within the remote configuration core module of the `dd-trace-java` project. Its purpose is to validate the correct behavior and transitions of remote configuration states.

This file provides a no-operation (noop) implementation of the `PollingRateHinter` interface. It does nothing when a polling rate is suggested, serving as a placeholder or default when hinting is not desired.
This file defines a `PollerScheduler` class responsible for scheduling and rescheduling a configuration poller at a fixed, potentially adjustable, interval.

This file implements the default configuration poller responsible for periodically fetching and applying remote configurations from the Datadog agent or Remote Configuration service. It manages product-specific listeners, handles the polling schedule, and processes received configuration updates.

This class parses and encapsulates the components of a remote configuration key string, providing structured access to its organization, product, version, and configuration ID details. It ensures keys are valid and facilitates their use in remote configuration processes.
This class serves as a simple adapter for `ProductListener` that forwards configuration changes to a generic `ConfigurationChangesListener`, converting `ConfigKey` objects to strings.

Manages the state and application of remote configurations for a specific product, including detecting changes, notifying listeners, and handling errors. It tracks cached target files and configuration states, with special handling for the ASM_DD product.
Defines an interface for a listener that is notified when a configuration change has been applied.
Defines a functional interface for listening to and accepting changes in configuration values, notifying when a configuration key's content has been updated or removed.

This file defines a functional interface for listening to strongly-typed configuration changes and provides a utility to wrap a deserializer around a generic listener to convert it into a strongly-typed one.
This file defines a functional interface `PollingRateHinter` used to suggest a new polling rate, taking a `Duration` as input.

This interface defines a poller for remote configurations, providing methods to register and unregister various listeners for configuration changes across different products. It also includes methods to manage polling lifecycle and product capabilities.

Defines an enumeration of products for which remote configuration is applicable, listed in their processing order. These products represent different features or components within the Datadog ecosystem.
Defines the `ConfigKey` interface, which represents a unique identifier for a remote configuration item, specifying its product, organization, version, and configuration ID.
Defines an interface for listeners that process remote configuration updates. It specifies methods for accepting, removing, and committing configuration changes for a particular product.
Defines configuration keys and constants for Datadog's remote configuration feature within the tracing API, including settings for enabling, polling, URL, and integrity checks.

This file is a smoke test application designed to verify the dynamic configuration of service name mapping in Datadog tracing. It continuously creates spans with an original service name and checks if the service name dynamically updates to a mapped value.
This document provides a guide on how to add new configurations to the Java Library, covering their structure, priority, implementation steps, and verification process.
This file defines a data class, `Integration`, used to represent a specific integration within the telemetry system. It stores the integration's name and its enabled/disabled status.
This file provides global flags to indicate which subsystems (like Application Security) are currently active within the Datadog Java tracer bootstrap process.

This file defines a mechanism to manage and apply configuration settings that can be dynamically updated at runtime, typically via remote configuration. It allows a subset of the application's configuration parameters to be changed without requiring an application restart.

This file provides a utility class for parsing a string-based configuration that defines which methods of specific classes should be filtered or traced. It converts a specialized string format into a map associating class names with a set of method names.

This file defines and manages configuration settings for the Datadog Java tracer, importing numerous default values from `ConfigDefaults` for various features like AppSec, CI Visibility, Debugger, and IAST.

This file defines a singleton class `ServiceNameCollector` responsible for collecting and managing a limited set of unique service names (other than the primary service name) for an application, primarily for remote configuration or telemetry purposes.
This file defines constants representing various capabilities (features) that can be enabled or disabled remotely for Datadog's ASM and APM services, primarily used for remote configuration.

This file defines the default configuration settings for the Datadog Java tracer, including agent connection parameters, tracing behaviors, security features (AppSec, IAST), and other operational defaults.
This file defines constant strings representing configuration keys for various features related to debugging, dynamic instrumentation, and symbol database management within the Datadog Java tracer.

This class collects configuration settings from various origins (e.g., system properties, environment variables, remote config, defaults) used by the Datadog tracer. It provides a thread-safe mechanism to store and retrieve these settings, allowing for concurrent updates and collection.

This file defines the `ConfigSetting` class, which represents a single configuration entry with its key, value, origin, and metadata. It handles normalization, string conversion for various value types, and masks sensitive configuration values like API keys.

This file provides utility methods for converting and normalizing configuration-related strings, such as property names, environment variable names, and header tags, for consistent use within the Datadog tracer.

This file defines a utility class that provides methods to query and retrieve metadata about supported configuration options, including environment variables, their aliases, and deprecated names. It serves as an interface for accessing generated configuration data for 'Config Inversion'.

This file defines a data structure, `SupportedConfiguration`, which encapsulates metadata for a configuration property, including its version, type, default value, aliases, and the keys used to reference it.

This file provides a parser for stable configurations defined in YAML files. It reads a configuration file, processes templates, and selects the appropriate configuration based on environment variables, process arguments, or specific rules.

This file defines the `Selector` class, a data structure used to represent a configuration selection rule within a stable configuration provider. It parses configuration maps into typed selector objects, including origin, key, matches, and operator fields.

This directory contains Groovy test files for validating the configuration provider components within the `dd-trace-java` project's `config-utils` module. It ensures the correct bootstrapping and provision of configuration settings.

This file provides a test implementation of `SupportedConfigurationSource` to allow custom configuration data to be used in tests. It helps simulate various configuration states, including supported environments, aliases, and deprecated settings.

This file contains unit tests for the `ConfigHelper` class, which manages configuration inversion by resolving environment variables and their aliases. It verifies correct behavior for variable precedence, alias handling, caching, and different strictness policies.
Defines an enumeration for standard logging levels (TRACE, DEBUG, INFO, WARN, ERROR, OFF) and provides utility methods for string conversion and level comparison.
This file provides a static utility class to store and retrieve a description of logging settings, intended to be a globally accessible, immutable map.

This file defines the `LogLevelSwitcher` interface, which provides methods for temporarily changing logging levels at runtime. It allows switching to a new level, restoring the original level, and reinitializing logging settings.

This class provides a global singleton access point for dynamically switching and restoring logging levels across the application. It acts as a delegator, attempting to find and use a LogLevelSwitcher implementation from the underlying logging framework.

This directory serves as a placeholder for test resources within the `remote-config-core` module, specifically for test case 'rcte1'. It is part of the test suite for remote configuration, potentially representing a scenario where no specific external resources are required for testing.
This file defines `ReportableException`, a runtime exception intended for errors within the remote configuration client that should be explicitly reported.

This factory class is responsible for constructing HTTP requests, including their JSON body and headers, for the Datadog remote configuration poller, incorporating client information, configuration details, and Git metadata.

This file provides a custom Moshi JSON adapter for deserializing `java.time.Instant` objects from string representations in JSON. It specifically parses the string as an `OffsetDateTime` before converting it to an `Instant`.
This file defines `MissingContentException`, a runtime exception used within the remote configuration's TUF (The Update Framework) component to signal when expected content is not found.
Defines an exception that is thrown when a configuration integrity check fails within the remote configuration's TUF (The Update Framework) component.
Defines the data structure for requests sent by a client (e.g., a tracer) to a Remote Configuration service, including client metadata and information about cached configuration files.

This file defines a Moshi `JsonAdapter` that handles the serialization and deserialization of raw JSON content represented as `ByteString` objects. It allows `ByteString` to be treated as a direct JSON value.

Defines the structure for responses from a remote configuration service, including client configurations, target files, and cryptographic metadata. It handles parsing, validation (checksums, length), and access to the configuration data.

This file defines the `ConfigurationDeserializer` interface, which specifies how to deserialize binary content into a typed configuration value. It is a functional interface for converting byte arrays into specific configuration objects.

LLM Observability.description: Provides specialized observability for applications utilizing Large Language Models (LLMs). Tracks and visualizes LLM requests, prompts, and responses to monitor performance, cost, and quality of AI-powered features.

files.description: This file implements a `ValueWriter` for `AIGuard.ToolCall.Function` objects, serializing their name and arguments into a writable format. It defines how AI Guard function call data is structured for communication and serialization.
This class serializes an AIGuard.Message object into a structured, writable format, handling different content types (text, image URLs) and tool calls for AI interaction messages.
This file implements a custom serializer (`ValueWriter`) for `AIGuard.ToolCall` objects, specifically responsible for writing their ID and associated function details into a serializable format.

This directory contains Groovy test code for the LLM observability writer component, specifically focusing on its integration with the Datadog intake. It ensures the correct transmission of LLM observability data to the Datadog backend.

This file implements a mapper that serializes Datadog's internal LLM Observability (LLMObs) spans into a MessagePack format. It prepares LLM-specific span data, including custom tags and metrics, for transmission to the Datadog LLMObs intake API.
Defines a periodic action specifically for collecting LLM observation metrics, leveraging the LLMObsMetricCollector.
This file defines a metric collector specifically for LLM Observability (LLMObs) telemetry. It records and queues 'span finished' metrics with details like integration, span kind, and error status.

This file provides a utility for managing and accessing the current `AgentSpanContext` specifically for LLM Observability operations, allowing attachment and retrieval of LLM-related span contexts within the current execution scope.
This file defines constant string keys used for configuring LLM Observability features within the Datadog trace API. It centralizes configuration option names related to LLM integration and behavior.
This file defines well-known constant tags used for Large Language Model (LLM) observability within the Datadog tracing API, such as model name, provider, and session ID.

This interface defines the contract for an individual LLM Observation (LLM Obs) span, providing methods to annotate it with input/output, metadata, metrics, and tags, as well as to manage its lifecycle and retrieve its identifiers.

This file defines the public API for Datadog LLM Observability, providing static methods to create and manage various types of LLM-related spans (e.g., LLM, Agent, Tool, Workflow, Embedding, Retrieval) and submit evaluations. It also includes nested classes for data structures like tool calls, tool results, LLM messages, and documents.

This file provides a no-operation (noop) implementation of the LLMObsSpan interface, serving as a placeholder when LLM Observability features are disabled or not actively used. All methods in this class perform no action or return default/zero values.

This file provides a 'no-operation' or 'null object' implementation of the LLMObsSpanFactory interface. It returns no-op LLMObsSpan instances for all span creation methods, effectively disabling LLM observability tracing when active.

This directory contains Groovy-based test files for the `dd-trace-api` module. These tests specifically validate functionalities related to Large Language Model Observability (LLMObs) within the tracing API.
Defines the 'Evaluator' interface, a core component in Datadog's AI Guard API, responsible for performing evaluations based on messages and options.

This file defines the Java SDK for interacting with the Datadog AIGuard service, which evaluates AI prompts and responses for security threats. It provides methods for evaluating messages and data structures for AI conversation components and evaluation results.
Provides a no-operation (noop) implementation of the LLMObsEvalProcessor interface, effectively disabling LLM Operations evaluation processing.

This directory contains Groovy-based test code specifically for the `aiguard` component within the `dd-trace-api` module. It is responsible for ensuring the correct functionality and integration of the API's `aiguard` features through tests written in Groovy.
